adapted a projection-based approach, similar to that of projected
and improve utility. Although assuming an untrusted server, their proposed algorithm relies on the assumption that the server knows the clientsâ€™
and uses them to cluster clients to â€œpublicâ€ (those with larger privacy parameters) and â€œprivateâ€. As such, as we show,
is extremely vulnerable to when clients share a falsified value of their privacy parameters (often larger than their true values) with server. Also, they used aggregation strategy

even if the server knows clientsâ€™ true privacy parameters, this information is not a perfect indication of the â€œtrueâ€ noise level in their model updates, especially with heterogeneous privacy parameters and batch/dataset sizes
The current state of the art in local heterogeneous
calls for a robust algorithm that takes all the mentioned potential sources of heterogeneity across clients into account and achieves high utility and data privacy simultaneously.

locally and sends its noisy model updates to the server at the end of each round. Now, an important question is that what is an efficient aggregation strategy for the server to aggregate the clientsâ€™ noisy model updates? Intuitively, the server has to pay more attention to the less noisy updates. The challenge is that the server knows neither the noise added by each client
nor its amount. To answer the above question, we first analyze the behavior of the noise level in clientsâ€™ batch gradients in

, for a similar analysis of clientsâ€™ uploaded model updates. The result of this analysis is an idea we propose for the server to estimate the noise amount in each model update, which leads to an efficient aggregation strategy in

references: In this section, we investigate five main research questions about
, we have done a comparison in terms of the average test accuracy across clients. We observe that

in the appendix for detailed results). It achieves higher system utility by using an efficient aggregation strategy, where it assigns smaller weights to the model updates that are indeed more noisy and minimizes the noise level in the aggregation of clientsâ€™ model updates. The aggregation strategy of
is sub-optimal, as it can not take the batch size heterogeneity and privacy parameter heterogeneity into account simultaneously.
We have also compared different algorithms based on their convergence speed in
. While the baseline algorithms suffer from high levels of noise in the aggregated model update

enjoys its efficient noise minimization, which performs very close to the optimum aggregation strategy, and not only results in faster convergence but also improves utility. In contrast, based on our experiments, the baseline algorithms have to use smaller learning rates to avoid divergence of their training optimization. Note that fast convergence of
algorithms is indeed important, as the privacy budgets of participating clients does not let the server to run the federated training for more rounds.

with others based on clientsâ€™ desired privacy level and number of clients. As clients become more privacy sensitive, they send more noisy updates to the server, making convergence to better solutions harder.

shows the highest robustness to the larger noise in clientsâ€™ updates and achieves the highest utility, especially in more privacy sensitive scenarios, e.g., Dist8. Also, we observe that it achieves the highest system utility when the number of clients in the system increases. Furthermore, it is completely safe in scenarios that some clients report a falsified privacy parameter to the server (

data distribution across clients. What if the data distribution is moderately/highly heterogeneous? Assuming full participation of clients in round
, in order to have a useful RPCA decomposition
at the end of the round, two conditions should be met
: 1. There should be an underlying low-rank matrix
Whether the first condition is met or not mainly depends on how much heterogeneous the data split across clients is. Note that
should be low, and not necessarily close to 1. If we assume that the second condition is met, it was shown in Theorem 1.1 in
that the decomposition is guaranteed to work even if
Therefore, even if the data split across clients is moderately heterogeneous, we expect
to be successful in at least the decomposition task and the following noise estimation, given that the noise matrix
is sparse, and there are large enough number of clients
Whether the second condition is met or not, mainly depends on how much variation exists in the amount of noise in clientsâ€™ model updates, i.e., how (approximately) sparse the set
, this mainly depends on clientsâ€™ privacy parameters (
and is independent of whether the data split is i.i.d or not.

as an approximately sparse matrix, which validates our RPCA decomposition.

There have been multiple works in the literature , showing that
has adverse effects on fairness in ML systems making it impossible to achieve both fairness and

showed that accuracy of DP models drops much more for the underrepresented classes and subgroups, which yields to fairness issues. Interestingly, our Robust-HDP takes care of clients with minority data (i.e., those with small
) by assigning slightly larger weights to them at aggregation time, as shown in

. Similarly, WeiAvg assigns uniform weights to clients. Hence, when both batch size and privacy parameters are uniform across clients (i.e., homogeneous DPFL), we expect the weight assignments of Robust-HDP and WeiAvg to yield to a higher performance fairness across clients, while we expect DPFedAvg - which was designed for homogeneous DPFL - to improve system utility. Our experimental results further clarifies this. We use the mean values of the distributions Dist1, Dist3, Dist5, Dist7 and Dist9 from
. With these settings and using the Dirichlet data allocation mentioned before, we got the results in

references: , which showed the considerable effect of batch size of a client on the noise variance in its model updates. When batch size decreases, its noise variance increases fast. Hence, unlike the previous case with uniform batch sizes, it is now both the batch sizes and privacy parameters of clients that determine the noise variance in their model updates. The results in
are obtained in this case. Also,
compares the weight assignments by different algorithms.
no longer outperforms the baselines. To get a better understanding, lets have a look at the aggregation weight assignments by different algorithms for this setting in

.
First, the accuracy of RPCA decomposition in estimating
has again decreased compared to that in
data split. Second, despite this, the aggregation weights returned by
are still close to the optimum weights. However, the plot of assigned weights by
are more spiky than that in
: compared to the aggregation weights returned by
has assigned larger weights to the clients with larger privacy parameters

. Batch size of clients has a larger effect on the aggregation weights assigned to them. For instance client 59, which has batch size 128 and the second largest privacy parameter, has been assigned aggregation weight close to 0.18, while the same client got aggregation weight close to 0.05 when all clients used the same batch size (

). There are 6 clients whose aggregation weights sum to more than 0.5, i.e., these only 6 clients contribute to the aggregated model parameter more than the other 54 clients altogether. The reason behind this is that

aims at minimizing the noise level in the aggregated model update at the end of each round, and it has been successful in that. But the question is that, in this scenario with data heterogeneity, is this strategy beneficial for the utility of the final trained model too? Although, this strategy results in maximizing the trained model utility when the data split is
, it is not the case when we have data heterogeneity and batch size heterogeneity simultaneously, and the results in
confirm this. This is a limitation for

. However, we can provide a solution for it. Heterogeneity in batch sizes usually happens when clients have different memory budgets. Clients with low memory budgets can not use large batches, especially when training privately with
. As observed, when having data heterogeneity, this batch size heterogeneity deteriorates the performance of
. Despite the heterogeneity that may exist in clientsâ€™ memory budgets, they can use gradient accumulation explained in
to virtually increase their batch sizes to a uniform batch size (e.g., 128). In this case, we get back to the results in

works well most of the times. The cost that we pay is that clients with limited physical memory sizes have to spend more time locally during each global round, and the server should wait longer for these clients before performing each aggregation.
